column33: "A confirmation of the effects in further studies is warranted before the findings can be generalized to all young adults." Indeed!. Also the article says "supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.jenvp.2019.101319" but that website says "Data not available / Data will be made available on request"

column3: Correlational study and randomised controlled trial for understanding and changing red meat consumption: The role of eating identities
column8: daily text message reminders to promote the self-monitoring of red meat consumption
column33: this study seems *very* similar to the other Carofa 2017 paper but I believe they're different samples & outcomes.  Another "Theory of Planned Behavior" paper. "Supplementary data related to this article can be found at http:// http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.socscimed.2017.01.005" but then there's no data

column3: Randomised controlled trial of a text messaging intervention for reducing processed meat consumption: The mediating roles of anticipated regret and intention
column8: first an email about the recommended dosage of procssed meat consumption and then daily text message reminders to promote the self-monitoring of processed meat consumption
column33: This study is in a theoretical category of its own and we need to acknowledge that in the theoretical description. It is doing a pretty intrusive nudge in conjunction with health advice but in its own words it is doing theory of planned behaviorI suppose there is an argument for excluding this on the basis that we want to show *lasting* effects i.e. those that endure beyond treatment itself. But we included studies like this in the contact and prejudice metas and it does at least show that text messages produce more than a momentary effect

column3: Project PREVENT: A Randomized Trial to Reduce Multiple Behavioral Risk Factors for Colon Cancer
column8: education targeting behavioral risk factors for colorectal cancer among individuals who have been diagnosed with adenomatous colon polyps
column33: this outcome measure is pretty crude -- did a risk factor stay the same, increase, or decrease. food diary much more reliable. Also, it's borderline excludable because its methods aren't replicable -- the specific changes to the microenvironment “were not reported in detail, precluding more detailed analyses of this intervention." Alas. Noting here that it's stratified random assignment rather than cluster. Finally, this study reports costs for cost-effective estimates

column3: Cancer Prevention Among Working Class, Multiethnic Adults: Results of the Healthy Directions–Health Centers Study
column8: social-contextual approach ta geting multiple levels of influence on behaviors, with special attention to low literacy skills and the shared and unique features of culture across racial/ethnic groups
column9: red meat consumption (RMC) -- 3 or fewer servings per week
column33: Fine study; this and the other Emmons et al. 2005 paper are identified herein as "companion studies" and both are part of the " Harvard Cancer Prevention Program Project". Also provides cost-estimates for cost-effectiveness analyses. ITT also possible. Major focus is health considerd broadly, so outcomes include ceasing smoking and eating more fruits and veggies. I also might have missed the part of the study where it says how long treatment took so I am just saying it's the same as the other Emmons et al. study and treatment was 4 months and measurement was 4 months after that. protocol here https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/14674737/

column3: Promoting Behavior Change Among Working-Class, Multiethnic Workers: Results of the Healthy Directions–Small Business Study
column7: cancer prevention intervention designed to prompote healthy behaviors
column8: "integrated interventions focused on nutrition, physical activity, and occupational health and activities focused on individual risk factors"
column9: </= 3 servings of red meat per week
column33: nice study; too bad it found so little. Authors self-report it did not achieve statistical significance (the multivitamin effect was significant but there are a lot of tests being run here.) for this outcome p = .72

column3: Lowering Red Meat and Processed Meat Consumption With Environmental, Animal Welfare, and Health Arguments in Italy: An Online Experiment

column33: online study. the number of days participants eat meat was 1.78 (SD = 1.12):
